title: Security Controls: Quick Checks and Pitfalls

items: If it blocks access before impact, it's a preventive control.
If it discourages behavior, it's a deterrent control.
If it alerts or records evidence, it's a detective control.
If it restores after damage, it's a corrective control.
If it’s an alternate until the real fix, it's a compensating control.
If it tells users what to do, it's a directive control.
Mixing up category vs type (managerial/operational/physical/technical are categories; preventive/detective/etc. are types).
Assuming “physical” always means preventive (a sign is physical but directive/deterrent).
Treating backups as preventive (backups are typically corrective controls).
Forgetting that managerial controls can be detective (e.g., scheduled log review procedures).
